Having explained the skillful means of practice, next is the extensive explanation of the methods for dealing with demonic affairs.
The treatise states:

Some sentient beings, lacking the power of wholesome roots, are confused and disturbed by various demons, non-Buddhists, ghosts, and spirits. In their sitting meditation, they may manifest terrifying forms, or appear as attractive men and women.
One should be mindful that these are only mental objects, and they will then disappear, never causing harm.

They may manifest as celestial beings, bodhisattvas, or even the form of the TathÄgata with all the major and minor marks complete, expounding dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, or expounding giving, morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom, or speaking of equality, emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness, no enmity, no intimacy, no cause, no effect, ultimate emptiness and quiescence as the true nirvÄá¹‡a, or enabling people to know the events of their past lives and the future, to attain the knowledge of others' minds and unobstructed eloquence, causing sentient beings to crave for the fame and profit of the world.

They may also cause people to be frequently angry or happy, with an irregular temperament, to be very loving, to sleep a lot, to be sick a lot, with a lazy mind, or suddenly giving rise to vigor, only to abandon it later, giving rise to disbelief, with many doubts and worries.

They may cause one to abandon one's original superior practices and cultivate various miscellaneous practices instead, or to become attached to worldly affairs and be entangled in various ways. They are also able to enable people to attain various samÄdhis.
These are all attained by non-Buddhists, not true samÄdhi.

It may also cause a person to dwell in concentration for one day, two days, three days, up to seven days, attaining naturally fragrant and delicious food and drink, with a comfortable body and mind, neither hungry nor thirsty, causing people to become attached.
Or it may also cause a person's food intake to be irregular, sometimes much, sometimes little, with a changing complexion.
For this reason, practitioners should always use wisdom to contemplate, not allowing their minds to fall into the deviant net.
They should diligently maintain right mindfulness, neither grasping nor becoming attached, thus able to stay far away from these karmic hindrances.
One should know that all the samÄdhis possessed by non-Buddhists are not apart from the mind of views, love, and arrogance, because they crave worldly fame, profit, and respect.

As for the samÄdhi of suchness, one does not dwell in the appearance of views, does not dwell in the appearance of attainments, and even when emerging from concentration, one is not lazy or arrogant, and all afflictions gradually become less and less.
If ordinary beings do not practice this samÄdhi, it is impossible for them to enter the TathÄgata's lineage.
Because cultivating the various worldly dhyÄna samÄdhis often gives rise to attachment to taste, relies on the view of self, is bound to the three realms, and is shared with non-Buddhists.
If one is not protected by good and wise friends, then one gives rise to the views of non-Buddhists.
The treatise says:
In this very gate there are two gates.
What are the two?
The first is the gate of concise explanation, concise indication, and dhÄraá¹‡Ä«; the second is the gate of extensive explanation, extensive indication, and scattered analysis.
In the first gate there are five gates.
What are the five?

The first is the gate of the different levels of sentient beings; the second is the gate of the false persons who create obstacles; the third is the gate of revealing the functions of their activities; the fourth is the gate of revealing the methods of counteracting practices; the fifth is the gate of revealing the benefits obtained through the power of counteracting causes; these are the five.
As for the gate of the differences in superiority and inferiority of sentient beings, it is because the two kinds of sentient beings are each different.
What are the two?
First, sentient beings with complete causes and conditions, and second, sentient beings with deficient causes and conditions.
Sentient beings with completeness have five things.
Sentient beings with deficiency lack four things.
What are the five completions?
First, completion of faith, because of deep love and joy;
second, completion of people, because of being able to protect;
third, completion of the Dharma, because of being able to skillfully penetrate the distinction between right and wrong;
fourth, completion of time, because of being in accordance with what is appropriate;
fifth, completion of nature, because of having true nature.
These are called the five.
If there are sentient beings who have these five things, there will never be any obstacles.
What are the four deficiencies?
It is because they are contrary to the previous four.
If there are sentient beings who, although having true nature, lack these four things, they will never be free from obstacles.
In this text, it should be known that the deficient ones are taken.
As the original text says, Some sentient beings lack the power of wholesome roots.
Having explained the aspect of the superiority and inferiority of sentient beings, next is the aspect of the person who creates obstacles.
Although there are innumerable persons who create obstacles, they do not go beyond four types.
What are the four?
They are demons, non-Buddhists, ghosts, and spirits. These are the four.
As for demons, there are four kinds of great demons with thirty-two thousand demon followers.
As for non-Buddhists, there are ninety-six kinds of great non-Buddhists with ninety-three thousand followers.
As for ghosts, there are ten kinds of great ghosts with five thousand one hundred and thirty-two kinds of ghost followers.
As for spirits, there are fifteen great spirits with five thousand one hundred and thirty-two kinds of spirit followers.
All these types obstruct and disturb the true teaching, causing it to go towards the wrong path, and are therefore called the wrong path.
The distinctions in names and meanings of demons and non-Buddhists are clearly explained in the Appearance Sutra, so I will not explain them here.
Since the Appearance Sutra does not clearly explain ghosts and spirits, I will now create a brief explanation of their essentials.
What are the names of the ten ghosts?

The first is the Chabiduti ghost, the second is the Igarashi ghost, the third is the Itigadati ghost, the fourth is the Banagunta ghost, the fifth is the Rarairati ghost, the sixth is the Bannitian ghost, the seventh is the Aami ghost, the eighth is the Shakabaani ghost, the ninth is the Taataiti ghost, and the tenth is the Titic ghost. These are the ten.
What are the uses of these ten ghosts?
If it is the first ghost, it may create daytime realms, nighttime realms, realms of the sun, moon, and stars, or seasonal realms, transforming as appropriate.
If the second ghost creates various smells, various clothes, and various plants and trees, it changes according to the situation.
If the third ghost creates the realms of earth, water, fire, and wind, it changes according to the situation.
If the fourth ghost creates the realm of flying and soaring, it changes according to the situation without obstruction.
If the fifth ghost creates the realm of the opening and closing of the sense faculties, it changes according to the situation without obstruction.
If the sixth ghost creates the realm of relatives, which may exist or not, it changes according to the situation without obstruction.
If the seventh ghost creates the realm of old and young, it changes according to the situation without obstruction.
If the eighth ghost creates the realm of having wisdom or not having wisdom, it changes according to the situation without obstruction.
If the ninth ghost creates the realm of non-existence, it changes according to the situation without obstruction.
If the tenth ghost creates various realms such as the sounds of scorpions, flies, ants, dragons, tigers, and lions, it changes according to the situation without obstruction.
This is called function.
What power does each of these functions rely on to be accomplished?
Each is accomplished by relying on three things.
What are the three?
First, the teacher; second, the teachings; third, practice.
The teacher refers to the one who teaches, the teachings refer to what is learned, and practice refers to past cultivation. These are called the three.
These ten ghosts are always inseparable, moving together and turning together to create obstacles.
The names of their functions are established according to their increase, like the first one.

How are demons and non-Buddhists distinguished?

As for what is called demons, they cause one to do evil things. As for what is called non-Buddhists, they cause one to abandon good things. The two kinds of distinctions should be understood in this way.
How are ghosts and spirits distinguished?
Obstructing the body is a ghost, obstructing the mind is a spirit. The two kinds of distinctions should be understood in this way.
How should these four obstacles be treated?
Herein, there are four kinds of antidotes.
What are the four?
First, the antidote of following and turning; second, the antidote of opposing and contradicting; third, the antidote of proceeding together; fourth, the antidote of neither together nor apart.
As for the antidote of following and turning, it is the unobstructed and unhindered antidote.
Namely, if outsiders do such things to disturb the practitioner's mind, the disturbed practitioner should think like this:

As for the treatment of opposing and contradicting each other, it is the treatment of distinguishing and opposing each other.

This is called the treatment of opposing and contradicting each other.
As for the treatment of accompanying, it is the treatment of fully turning together, namely, at one time fully turning the two treatments of opposing and following, without leaving turning.
This is called the characteristic of the treatment of accompanying.

As for the non-dual counteragent, it is the counteragent of no-thought and no-reliance, which means having nothing to think about, nothing to worry about, nothing to be attached to, and nothing to seek in all dharmas, because the mind abides in stillness and non-abiding.

What are the two?

Namely, all the above-mentioned evil kinds manifest the images of the six paths to disturb the practitioner's mind.

The gate of the general characteristics and functions of karmic activities has already been explained. Next, the gate of the Dharma of penetrating and counteracting practices will be explained.
It is said that sentient beings should contemplate in this way:
All dharmas are only the single measure of mind, without any external dharmas.
Since there are no external objects, how can a single mind-dharma act as an obstruction to another single mind-dharma?
Also, a single mind-dharma does not act as liberation for another single mind-dharma, without obstruction, without the matter of liberation.

A single mind-dharma, one is precisely the mind, the mind is precisely one, there is no separate mind apart from one, there is no one apart from the mind, one subsumes the dharma realm, the mind subsumes the dharma realm, the realm of immeasurable, boundless, deluded thoughts is quiescent and unarisen, the middle of the middle, free from characteristics, all dharmas are equally one taste, one characteristic, no characteristics, producing a kind of bright, radiant, ocean-like mind-ground, the winds of the winds forever cease, the waves of the waves completely abide, this is called the characteristic of penetrating the antidote.
Why is it so?
If all practitioners do not return to this gate of the antidote, there is no way to destroy the wrong paths and subdue deluded attachments.
As the scripture says, One should be mindful that only the mind exists, and the objects will then cease, and one will never be troubled.

First, the gate of manifesting human characteristics to inspire faith; second, the gate of manifesting speech to confuse consciousness; third, the gate of attaining the wisdom of the three times to deceive people; fourth, the gate of not leaving the worldly bonds and entanglements; fifth, the gate of the impermanence of the mind nature to create confusion; sixth, the gate of causing the attainment of deviant samÄdhi that is not true; seventh, the gate of exhorting practitioners to leave the deviant; eighth, the gate of discriminating the true and false to make them understood.
